entry.title: Re: SAP MDG vs ​SimpleMDG
entry.content: I worked closely with both Laidon Sales and Development on SimpleMDG a couple of years ago. Let's just say that it's a cool product with an attractive and user friendly front end. The problem until recently was the lack of deep SAP S4 ERP expertise on the back end. Consequently incorrect SimpleMDG field settings (e.g. Material records) gave so many activation and basic governance errors that SimpleMDG, even the Sales demo system, was practically unusable. This mean't that a significant amount of development time and effort had to be spent fixing basic functionality on new customer projects. Hopefully things have improved since then.

entry.title: Missing Legally Required Company Address Fields for E Invoicing: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ↔ External
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I’m currently working on an e‑invoicing integration between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and an external Peppol‑compliant e‑invoicing platform for Belgium.
During the design of the outbound invoice interface, we ran into a challenge regarding the retrieval of mandatory seller address information required for Belgian e‑invoicing.

Issue

Belgian e‑invoicing regulations require the invoice to include the seller’s registered address (street, number, postal code, city, country, etc.).
This data should be sourced from the Company Code issuing the billing document.

However, in S/4HANA Public Cloud, we have observed the following:

  • The Billing Document APIs (e.g., API_BILLING_DOCUMENT_SRV) do not expose the selling company’s address.
  • The Company Code API (e.g., API_COMPANYCODE_SRV) does not provide address fields.
  • We identified the Manage Location API (API_LOCATION_SRV), which does contain address‑relevant information — but it is not available for our tenant because the required scope items are not activated, and they cannot be activated at this stage.
  • We have not found any alternative released API or CDS view providing Company Code address data.

Impact

Because these fields are missing from all accessible APIs, we cannot populate the legally required seller information in the payload sent to the e‑invoicing platform. This prevents successful validation of outbound invoices within the Belgian Peppol framework.

Questions for the Community

  1. Where can we retrieve the official Company Code / legal entity address in S/4HANA Public Cloud without relying on the Location API?
  2. What is SAP’s recommended approach for extracting mandatory seller information for e‑invoicing integrations?
  3. Has anyone implementing Belgian e‑invoicing in Public Cloud found a standard or alternative solution to this gap?

Environment

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Outbound billing via OData APIs
  • E‑invoicing via Peppol
  • Country: Belgium

Any insights, experience, or recommended design patterns would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you!

entry.title: Re: SAP Business Data Cloud landscape (Q/Prod)
entry.content:
SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) can be set up either as separate instances for Quality and Production (BDC-Q and BDC-PROD) or as a single BDC instance with multiple tenants for Datasphere (DSP) and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). The right choice depends on priorities around isolation, cost, compliance, and operational complexity.

Separate Instances:

Full physical separation of environments
Higher licensing and infrastructure costs
Independent scaling, maintenance, and backups
Strongest isolation and compliance posture
More operational overhead and risk of configuration drift

Single Multi-Tenant Instance:

Logical separation via tenants (DSP-Q, DSP-PROD, SAC-Q, SAC-PROD)
Lower cost through shared resources and optimized capacity
Centralized maintenance and monitoring
Simplified operations and governance
Potential risks from shared resource contention or unified failure points

Integration & Operations

Separate instances provide complete isolation for DSP and SAC integrations and testing.
A multi-tenant setup offers tenant-level data isolation, shared compute/storage, unified identity management, and streamlined deployment pipelines.

Cost & Risk

Separate instances incur higher licensing, infrastructure, and support costs but minimize cross-environment risks.
Multi-tenant setups reduce costs and administrative burden but require strong governance to mitigate shared-resource and data-exposure risks.

Best Practices & Recommendations

Large or highly regulated enterprises often prefer separate instances for strict isolation and compliance.
Organizations focused on cost optimization and operational simplicity typically favor a single multi-tenant BDC.

Decision Guidance

Choose separate instances for strict compliance, independent scaling, and maximum isolation.
Choose single multi-tenant for cost efficiency, simplified operations, and when logical separation is sufficient.

What to think?

Perform a cost-benefit analysis
Review compliance and security requirements
Validate the target architecture with SAP support

Overall, multi-tenancy is cost-effective and operationally simpler, while separate instances offer stronger isolation and compliance assurance.

entry.title: mdk mobile service app no longer working after SAP note 3566727
entry.content:
Hello everyone, i am facing a very urgent issue.

after SAP note 3566727 - Remplacement du certificat racine dans SAP BTP, environnement Cloud Foundry, MDK apps no longer working on android 13 and under devices. Our app works on zebra devices that have android 13 and they cant start anymore.

We are getting: javax.net.ssl.error:SSLHandshakeException : java.security.cert.certPathValidatiorException.

We opened a sap ticket and recieved a pdf file with this:

Resolution
Upgrade the older device to Android 14 or higher
OR
Following google doc:
https://developer.android.com/privacy-and-security/security-config#CustomTrust
, another way does not need to install the certificate into device, and steps are as below.
1. access the cockpit of cf mobile service, download certificate from web browser.
2. without installing this certificate into device, just add certificate into client app, such as res/raw
3. add network_security_config.xml into res/xml, then apply it in AndroidManifest.xml file.
network_security_config.xml
<network-security-config>
<base-config>
<trust-anchors>
<certificates src="system"/>
<certificates src="@raw/trusted_roots"/>
</trust-anchors>
</base-config>
</network-security-config>
AndroidManifest.xml
<application
...
android:networkSecurityConfig="@xml/network_security_config">

We have a hybrid app developed in BTP devspace with js and cloud build, branded, but i dont have an AndroidManifest.xml in the branded zip or the workspace, nor can the client update the android devices. How can i do the above resolution?

Please advise.

RaulM

 

 

note:

i added android manifest in ...\App_Resources_Merge\Android\src\main\,  client certificate downloaded from mobileservices cockpit in App_Resources_Merge\Android\src\main\res\raw\ and network_security_config.xml in App_Resources_Merge\Android\src\main\res\xml\ with:  

network_security_config.xml:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<network-security-config>
<base-config>
<trust-anchors>
<certificates src="system"/>
<certificates src="@raw/nameofcertificate"/>
</trust-anchors>
</base-config>
</network-security-config> and 

AndroidManifest.xml:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<manifest xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android">

<application
android:networkSecurityConfig="@xml/network_security_config" />

</manifest> 

as in the pdf i got from SAP,  but still the same issue

entry.title: SAP Commerce Cloud and Consumer Industries 2025 Year in Review
entry.content:
2025 Year in Review: Continued Investment and Growth in SAP Commerce Cloud and Consumer Industries! 

It’s been an exciting year. SAP Commerce Cloud and the many products that support Consumer Industries rolled out many cutting-edge capabilities, all designed to continuously deliver connected, trusted, and smooth commerce experiences that drive profitable growth for our customers. These include AI features, B2B Self-Service Portal, SAP Open Payment Framework, Search Service, SAP Customer Loyalty Management, and many more. In total, we delivered 171 new Commerce features and performance improvements across 65 releases, many of which were from customer requests. 

Now, let’s dive into the highlights! 

SAP Commerce Cloud named Leader in Gartner Magic Quadrant for Digital Commerce for 11th year in a row 

SAP has proudly been named a Leader in the 2025 Gartner Magic Quadrant for Digital Commerce. SAP remains the only vendor consistently recognized 11 times since 2014. 

SAP Commerce Cloud continues to empower organizations to drive growth and profitability. Key capabilities that distinguish SAP Commerce Cloud in digital commerce include: 

  • B2B Self-Service Portal with native ERP integration
  • Extensive enterprise reach
  • Support for complex business models

SAP Order Management Services Named Leader by IHL Group

SAP Order Management Services continued its strong market momentum, achieving a Leader position in The Order Management Market 2025 report by IHL Group. This recognition highlights the value of SAP Order Management delivers by streamlining operational complexity, delivering on customer promises, and enabling seamless omnichannel customer experience.  

IHL Group emphasized SAP Order Management Service's modular, composable architecture as well as native integration across the SAP ecosystem. The report also noted SAP Order Management Services' expanding AI capabilities as one of the key differentiators, empowering organizations for more intelligent order management processes. 

SAP Commerce Cloud - Cyber Week Results 

We had another huge Cyber Week to kick off the biggest shopping season. SAP Commerce Cloud: 

  • Powered $17.8B in Gross Merchandise Value (GMV), a +40% year-over-year (YoY) increase
  • Peak per minute of $2.3B in GMV and 11K orders
  • We achieved these impressive results with 100% uptime! 

This is a testament to the support and rock-solid platform that helps our customers keep up with demand during the busiest time. 

And with the rise of agentic AI, read how “2025 is the Last Year Online Shopping Starts with a Search Bar, Not a Sentence.” 

Expanding Retail and Fashion Capabilities with S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

We’ve added many new capabilities to Retail, Fashion, and Vertical Business with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The new features showcase our continued dedication to delivering innovative solutions and comprehensive end-to-end process coverage for retailers to stay competitive in the fast-paced environment. 

With features like order capturing in stores to handle hybrid scenarios and Mass Assignment of Products to Assortment modules, retailers save time with streamlined processes and reduce operational bottlenecks. 

For fashion retailers, value-added services charge codes can be added during order processing to increase the value of the product for the recipient and provide transparency on service-related items. 

We’ve added localization to many more countries, including India, Australia, Mexico, Singapore, the UK, Belgium, Denmark, South Korea, and Chile, among others. This brings our total to 44 countries. By addressing local tax, legal, and market-specific requirements, SAP S/4HANA Cloud ensures retailers worldwide can leverage its capabilities. 

By combining industry expertise, advanced functionality, and global compliance, SAP empowers retailers and fashion brands to stay ahead in an omnichannel, customer-centric world.  

Maximize Promotion Impact with SAP Revenue Growth Management 

SAP Revenue Growth Management had many new features to help customers turn every dollar of trade spend into measurable sales and margin growth: 

  • Faster Claims Processing – Accelerate trade-promotion rebate settlements by matching deductions and invoices to planned promotions, validating claims, and creating credit memos in S/4HANA
  • AI-Powered Promotion Creation – Assist creation of single promotions and generate multiple draft promotions quickly using natural language prompts and guided workflows 


Create Promotions with AI 

  • Flexible Units of Measure – Plan and track promotions in multiple Units Of Measure, converting between trading units (TU), consumer units (CU), or normalized units (NU) for greater accuracy
  • Custom KPIs – Configure new KPIs and rules beyond the 68 standard options for tailored analytics and reporting. Use throughout the application, use customer KPI’s in account KPI tracking aswell as dashboards & analytics.  


Custom KPI creation 

  • Configurable Fund Management – Configure different fund types to further support control or trade spend with fund creation, budget adjustments, and spend tracking
  • Analytics Dashboards – Access real-time insights and P&L analysis for individual promotions via embedded SAP Analytics Cloud
  • Custom Promotion Types – Define scope, levels, and spend types to create promotion types beyond standard short- and long-term options
  • Account Plan Configuration – Adapt account plans for different customer types, including baseline volume management and future indirect promotion planning. 


Account Plan Type configuration 

SAP Customer Loyalty Management: Stronger Connections for Business Growth

The recently launched SAP Customer Loyalty Management helps customers drive long-term relationship development and business growth. The solution captures customer data and loyalty engagement in a cloud-based wallet that acts as a “loyalty profile”, to better understand individual customer motivations and enhance segmentation and targeted marketing campaigns. 

The platform supports a wide range of loyalty models, all managed through a unified interface. Integration with SAP Cloud ERP Private and SAP Business Suite ensures visibility into loyalty-related financial metrics, helping organizations measure ROI and guide future investments. Marketing teams can track promotion performance, redemption rates, and liabilities, enabling them to scale loyalty strategies effectively within existing enterprise systems.


SAP Customer Loyalty Management 

AI Innovations Driving Commerce Forward 

Artificial Intelligence remains at the forefront of digital transformation—especially with the rise of agentic AI. We’ve introduced a range of new capabilities designed to make commerce smarter, faster, and more personalized. 

AI Shopping Agent 

Our enhanced Shopping Agent now goes beyond intent detection and natural language processing. It delivers tailored product recommendations directly on product pages and supports conversational actions like adding items to the cart or retrieving order details—order number, date, shipping address, and total—without leaving the chat. 

Stock awareness is built in, giving merchants control over whether out-of-stock items appear in recommendations. This transparency reduces cart abandonment and improves customer confidence. For B2B scenarios, merchants can also enable bulk stock inquiries, ensuring buyers get accurate availability for large orders.  


AI Shopping Agent 

Catalog Optimization Agent 

This agent reviews product images and suggests improvements to boost discoverability and conversions. A human review step ensures quality before updates go live, reducing manual effort while maintaining brand integrity.  

Product Image Designer 

Easily refine visuals by removing unwanted objects, isolating products, or adjusting AI-generated images to meet brand standards. These enhancements help create compelling, accurate product imagery that drives engagement.  

Digital Service Agent  

Enhance the customer self-service experience and increase contact center efficiency by providing swift, informed support grounded in business knowledge from specific data sources to answer questions. Digital Service Agent addresses complex customer queries, seamlessly transitioning to human agents when needed. 

Digital Service Agent works with AI Shopping Agent, covering new use cases that deliver even more customer value. With both agents, customers benefit from unified support throughout their entire shopping journey, including assistance with post-sale requests.  


Digital Service Agent 

Joule Studio AI agent builder capability 

You can now create AI agents for SAP CX applications to retrieve information, complete tasks, and run autonomous actions using enterprise data from SAP Customer Experience and SAP Knowledge Graph. For example, a returns agent can be built to trigger returns execution based on insights and recommendation from the AI Agent on returns pending approval.

Joule Studio, part of SAP Build, provides developers with a comprehensive suite of low-code, no-code tools to easily extend Joule capabilities and orchestrate business workflows, including CX across SAP and non-SAP applications. Learn how to activate Joule Studio and start building, testing, and deploying AI Agents. 

B2B Self-Service Portal Empowers Customers with 24/7 Access 

Designed as an SAP Cloud ERP add-on, the SAP B2B Self-Service Portal offers post-purchase transparency without the complexity of a full commerce implementation. Launch in weeks using partner packages, then scale to SAP Commerce Cloud without data migration. Buyers gain real-time access to orders, delivery status, and invoices—reducing support overhead and improving satisfaction. 


B2B Self-Service Portal 

Reduce Payment Integration Complexity with Open Payment Framework 
Now extended for B2B transactions, this framework delivers secure, streamlined payment experiences with built-in validation, error handling, and feature toggles. Support for both account-based and digital payment options ensures flexibility—all managed centrally. 

Drive Conversions with Smarter Search Experiences

Helping customers find the right product quickly is key to boosting sales and improving satisfaction. Search Service is designed to deliver precision and flexibility, offering features that elevate product discovery: 

  • Customizable Indexing and Scoring – Fine-tune search results to align with your business priorities
  • Intelligent Spell Correction & Suggestions – Turn typos into successful searches with smart word recommendations
  • Variant Grouping – Present related product variations together for a cleaner, more intuitive experience
  • Configurable Search Bar – Adapt the look and feel of your search interface to match your brand identity 

Pair it with Intelligent Selling Services to unlock AI-powered search capabilities—delivering personalized results, trending suggestions, and intent-driven recommendations that convert.  


Search Service

Streamlined Integrations for Pricing and Enhanced S/4 HANA-based Order Management  

Managing pricing and promotions just got easier! With the latest SAP S/4HANA integrations, SAP Commerce Cloud users can now handle product pricing and order value calculations accurately and consistently from one centralized location.

  • B2B Price Calculation – SAP Variant Configuration and Pricing applies backend pricing rules while handling cart calculations independently, reducing system load. Define product models and pricing rules once and apply them universally
  • Omnichannel Promotions – Leverage SAP Omnichannel Promotion Pricing to create multi-code coupons for targeted campaigns across SAP Customer Experience solutions like SAP Emarsys, delivering personalized offers that boost sales, loyalty, and brand awareness.  

 Order Management with SAP S/4HANA enhances visibility and saves time. 

  • With SAP S/4HANA order integration, attached documents like product specifications or special instructions, along with detailed status information from SAP S/4HANA document flow, are now visible directly in order history. Furthermore, synchronizing products from SAP S/4HANA to display in order history and order details is no longer required. Customers benefit from a comprehensive, 360-degree view of orders, including those not submitted through SAP Commerce Cloud and those containing products not listed in the SAP Commerce Cloud catalogue. 

New APIs Deliver Smarter Self-Service and Automation

We have introduced powerful APIs to simplify operations, reduce manual effort, and improve efficiency: 

  • Scaling Configuration API – Automate sandbox scaling to save consumption credits and reduce errors. Retrieve current scaling, schedule environment actions like hibernation or wake-up, and enforce off-hours policies through scripts—giving DevOps teams greater control
  • Cloud Portal API – Manage dozens of endpoints effortlessly. Programmatically control configurations, including Maintenance Mode, and automate maintenance toggles across environments for faster, error-free operations
  • SSL Certificate Management API – Eliminate manual certificate swaps with automated updates via API. Integrate with your CA/SCM for faster processes, fewer mistakes, lower outage risk, and scalable governance.  

Event Notifications Framework with Guaranteed Delivery 

Integrating with your preferred systems is easier than ever thanks to our configurable Event Notifications Framework. Choose from over 140 prebuilt events—including Order Placed, User Account Deleted, Product Reviewed, and more—covering transactional, user, and backend activities. 

Set up real-time messaging to third-party systems using Webhooks in Backoffice, complete with a visual configurator that minimizes custom coding and maximizes flexibility. 

To ensure critical updates never get lost, we have introduced At-least-once delivery (ALOD). This feature automatically retries failed webhook transmissions, guaranteeing that essential events are delivered at least once and protecting your most important data.  


Webhook Events with At Least Once Delivery enabled 

Flexible Purchasing with B2B PunchOut for Composable Storefront 

B2B PunchOut gives buyers a smooth way to browse a supplier’s online catalog and transfer selected items directly into their procurement system as a requisition. The process includes automatic login and logout for a frictionless experience. 

With PunchOut integrated into the Composable Storefront, the shopping cart becomes the foundation for creating a purchase requisition. This requisition is then routed for internal approval within the buyer’s organization. Once approved, the order flows back to the supplier’s site for processing. There’s no traditional checkout button—instead, when you’re ready, simply click “Back to Requisition” to finalize the transaction in your procurement system.  


Shopping cart page in PunchOut session  

Unlock Data Quickly with SQL View Gateway  

SQL View Gateway gives customers self-service access to SAP Commerce Cloud data, making analytics, reporting, and integrations faster and more efficient—helping you turn insights into smarter decisions. 

Our new real-time database replicas provide direct SQL access, so you can build dashboards, trigger internal workflows, feed data into lakes, and more—all without impacting your production environment

Cut Costs with Non-Production Environment Hibernation

Take control of your commerce operations by hibernating non-production environments whenever you don’t need them—safely and without any risk of data loss or recovery issues. You can even schedule hibernations, for example, after finishing a performance test campaign. The result? Significant cost savings, smarter resource allocation, and stronger security and compliance.  

We rolled out a self-service option that lets you trigger hibernation directly from the Cloud Portal or via API—no need to involve SAP support. It’s a simple way to make your IT infrastructure more efficient, secure, and cost-effective. 

Seamless Omnichannel Transactions with SAP Order Management Services 

The Central Order Service in SAP Order Management Foundation lays the groundwork for true omnichannel experiences. It seamlessly connects online and offline transactions, enabling scenarios such as BORIS (Buy Online, Return in Store) and BISRO (Buy in Store, Return Online) for maximum flexibility. Businesses also gain a 360-degree view of customer purchase histories, driving deeper personalization and engagement. 

The rollout of API V3 significantly improves scalability and performance, ensuring SAP Order Management Foundation can meet the demands of modern commerce environments. 

The new Availability Push feature for SAP Order Management for Sourcing and Availability proactively delivers up-to-date stock information to external systems like web shops and marketplaces. This reduces order cancellations caused by outdated data. Updates can be tailored by channel, product, and frequency, sending only changes in stock levels for efficient communication. 

The Type Code feature in SAP Omnichannel Sales Transfer and Audit introduces robust validation for ERP type codes. Customers can configure acceptable codes, preventing invalid entries from being processed and halting transactions until corrections are made—ensuring data integrity and compliance. 

Upskill Employees with WalkMe Adoption Platform  

With WalkMe Premium for SAP CX, users receive real-time, role-based guidance and automation within SAP CX solutions, such as SAP Commerce Cloud. The embedded training and contextual help simplify complex workflows, accelerates onboarding, and ensures consistent execution. Organizations improve user adoption and unlock more value in their SAP CX investment.  

Partner Solutions Driving Innovation 

Our expanding partner ecosystem on the SAP Store continues to strengthen SAP Commerce Cloud with powerful solution extensions.

Newstore brings a mobile-first, SAP-ready solution with pre-built integrations across SAP commerce offerings to deliver faster, smarter service in retail stores. Its intuitive associate app streamlines workflows, reduces hardware dependency, and seamlessly connects digital and in-store experiences. From store fulfillment to task management and personalized service, Newstore helps retailers optimize operations in high-touch environments.  


NewStore  

Revers.io extends SAP Order Management Services to enhance returns and post-sales processes. This pre-composed solution simplifies returns, repairs, and product reuse, offering an integrated self-service experience. Automated workflows across the after-sales chain reduce lead times, cut reverse logistics costs, and ease customer service workloads—all while accelerating time-to-market. 

Looking Ahead: 2026 and Beyond 

The innovations we delivered in 2025 underscore SAP’s commitment to helping businesses stay ahead in a rapidly evolving landscape. As we move into 2026 and beyond, our priority remains clear: delivering solutions that create measurable value, scale effortlessly, and enable frictionless customer experiences.  

Together, we’re shaping the next chapter of commerce and consumer industries. 
Here’s to an exciting journey ahead and wishing you a joyful holiday season and a successful new year!  

Additional Resources 

  • Retail, fashion and vertical business in SAP S/4HANA Cloud public edition 2508 
  • Q1 2025 SAP Commerce Cloud recap 
  • Q2 2025 SAP Commerce Cloud recap 
  • Q3 2025 SAP Commerce Cloud recap 
  • Sign up for Q4 2025 SAP Commerce Cloud release recap webcast 
  • Replay SAP Commerce Cloud: Year in Review and 2026 Roadmap webcast 

 Please share your feedback in a comment and follow our SAP Commerce Cloud topic page to connect with the community!

entry.title: Re: A Wish for CLI-Based ABAP
entry.content:
What an interesting read.

From my viewpoint, started with SAP Logon like 11 years ago or so and quickly adopted eclipse ADT, eclipse still feels like a good middle ground and is currently my preferred IDE for backend developments simply because the terminal can become overwhelming quickly if not fully familiar with the commands (though that might just be a matter of getting used to it).

The decision to bring backend developments to VScode seems like a good idea for several reasons.
For me the most appealing thing in that is simply to have just one IDE for both backend and frontend developments (I remember a brief period where I was able to do backend, frontend, and native HANA developments all in eclipse).
Currently it is still a wait for ABAP in VScode, and it might take a while for it to catch up with eclipse ADT.
I am curious what it will bring, and if somehow any IDE can let AI act directly on the backend code it would be a big empowerment for efficiency (that is without downloading the whole system locally and then uploading again what changed,. that is where git might one day provide a workable solution).

For now I am sticking with eclipse for 98% of backend developments, the missing 2% is for things like webdynpro that are not workable in eclipse :D.

entry.title: Re: Connecting SAP Data Warehouse Cloud OData API with PowerBI via a Blank Query
entry.content:
Thank you @gustavokath very informative and helpful post. If its helpful for fellow members, I was stuck at the "Generate Access and Refresh Tokens" step for a longer than needed time because postman kept on throwing invalid grant type error at me. Finally, I was able to get it to work. Below is what I configured in postman:

Method - Post

URL - Pick up the Token URL from "App Integration" page of Datasphere -> System -> Administration -> App Integration

Params:

1> Key- grant_type; value - authorization_code

2>Key - response_type; value - token

Authorization:

Auth Type: Basic Auth

username - Enter client ID here (I did not need to change | to %7C) and Password - Enter client secret here.

Headers:

I did not make any changes here

Body:

1> key - grant_type; Value - authorization_code

2>key - code; Value - provide the code that you generated in step 2."generate code grant token".

3> redirect_uri - https://oauth.powerbi.com/views/oauthredirect.html

That's it and then click on Send to receive the access_token, refresh_token etc.

entry.title: ZZ field upload in the journal entries app is not populated the backend
entry.content:
Dear all,

I am currently working on an SAP S/4HANA On-Premise implementation and I am facing an issue with a custom ZZ field in the Journal Entry upload process.

Context

  • I have a custom ZZ field created in the CI_COBL extension.

  • According to SAP notes, this field needs to be published so it can be used in the Upload Journal Entries Fiori app.

  • I exposed and published the field as a Key User Custom Field extension in the Coding Block using transaction SCFD_EUI.

  • The S_ATO_SETUP was already configured.

Configuration Done

The field has been published and activated in the following apps and objects:

  • Journal Entry Item

  • FINS Substitution / Validation – Journal Entry Item

  • Manage Journal Entries

  • Post General Journal Entries

  • Target structure for field mapping

  • All OData and SOAP services related to FINS_CODING_BLOCK

Observed Behavior

  • The field is correctly published.

  • When I open the Upload Journal Entries app and download the Excel template, the custom field (ZZUEN) is present in the template.

  • However, when I fill the ZZUEN field in the template and upload it:

    • The journal entry is successfully posted.

    • The ZZUEN value is not populated in the corresponding ZZ field in ACDOCA.

Debugging and Analysis

  • I activated BADI_FINS_ACDOC_POSTING_EVENTS and implemented debugging logic to intercept the posting process.

  • The ZZ field exists in ACDOCA and is visible in the item structures passed to the BAdI methods.

  • However, the original frontend field (ZZ_1* field from the Excel / UI) is not available in the interface structures, so I cannot perform the mapping.

  • It seems the value is lost before reaching the posting BAdI.

Question

The process appears straightforward: expose the field via Custom Fields, activate it in the UI and services, and use it in the Upload Journal Entries app. While the field is technically available and visible in the template, it is not mapped to the backend ZZ field during posting.

  • Is there a specific BAdI or enhancement spot responsible for mapping custom fields from the XLSX layout to the backend coding block?

  • Is there any additional configuration required to ensure the custom field value is transferred from the Upload Journal Entries app to ACDOCA?

Any hints or guidance to resolve this issue would be highly appreciated.

Kind regards,
Francisco

entry.title: How Does HRIS Sync Handle Time Zones and Effective Dates for Global Users?
entry.content:
Hello Experts, 

We have only used Employee Central (EC) for users in the KST time zone so far.
However, we will soon be adding users in other time zones (e.g., the U.S., France, Mexico, and Australia).

As we introduce users in different time zones, we have a question regarding HRIS Sync. The HRIS Sync job is currently scheduled to run at 00:00 KST.

If the job runs based on KST (as shown in the table), we expect that for some countries the effective date may be treated as the previous day (i.e., processed one day earlier). We are concerned this could cause issues for processes such as hiring and termination. In particular, we suspect that terminations for users outside KST could be processed a day earlier and set users to Inactive prematurely.

We would appreciate your feedback on whether this assumption is correct.
If we are misunderstanding how HRIS Sync handles time zones and effective dates, please let us know.

KST2026-01-0100:00
UTC2025-12-3115:00
Paris2025-12-3116:00
London2025-12-3115:00
Mexico City2025-12-3109:00
AEST2026-01-0101:00


Thanks advance.

entry.title: Re: The "Create New Analysis" (READINESSCHECK) button is...
entry.content:
Although SAP Readiness Check continues to support S-user logins, the platform now requires the following two additional authorizations:
• Display SAP Readiness Check Analysis: Enables S-users to view all SAP Readiness Check analyses belonging to the customer number associated with their user ID.
• Manage SAP Readiness Check Analysis: Enables S-users to create, edit, delete, and share all SAP Readiness Check analyses belonging to their customer number.
To request these authorizations, please contact your company's Super Administrator(s) listed in Users & Contacts - SAP for Me. They have the authority to assign the required authorizations via S-User Management - SAP for Me.  
Alternatively, you can submit a self-service authorization request directly through SAP for Me. Access the request page using this link: https://me.sap.com/preferences/authorizations. You can also navigate to the Profile icon in the top-right corner of the SAP for Me header bar, select "My Settings," go to the "Authorizations and Functions" tab, and choose "Request Authorization."  

For additional details about SAP for Me's self-service authorization capabilities, you can refer to KBA 2891528. Further guidance is available the KBAs 3310759 and 3545701, which address the revised authorization concept and missing button issue in the SAP Readiness Check Dashboard.

entry.title: Re: partner determination ship to party
entry.content:
Why it happens is because, Partner determination procedure (VOPAN) defines which partner functions (Sold-to, Ship-to, Bill-to, Payer) are mandatory or optional for a given sales document type. Each account group (e.g., B001 vs. C001) has its own partner determination procedure assigned in customer master configuration. If the account group’s partner procedure doesn’t include Ship-to Party (or marks it differently), the system won’t propose it automatically in the sales order. That is why dealer 13200 (account group B001) behaves differently than dealers in C001.

Steps to resolve

  • Check account group settings in SPRO and verify which partner determination procedure is assigned to B001 vs. C001. Compare them — likely C001 has Ship-to Party included, while B001 does not.
  • Go to Partner Determination in VOPAN for Customer Master, ensure Ship-to Party (SH) is included in the procedure assigned to B001. Mark it as mandatory if you want the system to always propose it.
  • Confirm that ZREW uses the correct partner determination procedure. If ZREW is linked to a procedure that expects Ship-to but the customer’s account group doesn’t provide it, you’ll get the error.
  • The customer account group’s partner procedure and the sales order type’s partner procedure must align. If they mismatch, the system won’t propose Ship-to automatically.

In short, the error is not in ZREW itself but in the partner determination procedure assigned to account group B001. Align it with C001 or adjust ZREW’s procedure, and the issue will be resolved.

entry.title: Re: Exposing application service running in Kyma cluster using APIRule
entry.content:
@mbeljic Hello,

Check your host if you are using the wildcard directly in the host like:

hosts:
- fastapi-hello.*.c-123456.kyma.ondemand.com

then this may caused issue 
you should directly use the name in the host like
hosts:
- fastapi-hello.c-123456.kyma.ondemand.com


After the above correction check the CPI call as well if the CPI is calling the http request then this will fail (sometimes as DNS error depending on adapter)
http://fastapi-hello.c-123456.kyma.ondemand.com

 

The CPI must use the https request like
https://fastapi-hello.c-123456.kyma.ondemand.com

then there will be no exceptions

 

Hope the above steps resolve your issue...

entry.title: Re: MRP user exit/BAdI to filter BOM components by procur...
entry.content: The cleanest solution is to use BAdI MD_CHANGE_MRP_DATA or EXIT_SAPLM61C_001 to filter BOM components during MRP explosion, allowing only procurement type F items to generate requirements. But please be careful that suppressing E items means no planned orders will be created for them. If those items are needed elsewhere, you must ensure they are covered by other planning runs. Test thoroughly with simulation runs (MD02/MD03) before moving to production. Document the logic clearly, since this is a non-standard planning behavior.

FormPMReviewContentDetail: upsert failed: You do not have permission to save the form data for Key FormPMReviewContentDetail/formContentId=8601, FormPMReviewContentDetail/formDataId=5016 with the index 0."

Although the performance form is already in the user’s inbox, I am unsure about what exactly needs to be filled in the User ID field—should it be the employee to whom the performance form was launched, or the User ID of the person in the route step (i.e., the one importing the goal ratings via Integration Center)?

entry.title: Re: How We Retired almost 10% of Our Custom Code (And Counting) – Lessons from Real Life
entry.content:
Thanks @striezl for this guide!

I'm just wondering if one step might be missing in #6 "1. Simple programs without dependencies". Wouldn't the variants used to execute the program need to be deleted first in all relevant systems (PROD, TEST, DEV...) because you cannot easily get to them after a report was deleted? That's at least what we found out some years ago when we went through such a deletion exercise.

We do prep-work for eventual deletions by first marking executable programs as "incactive" if we notice e.g. via SUSG-data that they haven't been used in a long time (we started collecting data in 2020, so have a pretty good track record for that).

Cheers

Bärbel

entry.title: SAP Ariba Supplier Management & Risk 2602 Release Key Innovations Preview
entry.content:
Supplier Lifecycle & Performance

Ability to Restrict Hierarchy Level Selection for Department and Region in Questionnaire Configuration (SLP-2309)

With this feature, template creators can now configure hierarchy level selection restrictions for Department and Region question types in the same way they can for Commodity questions. Respondents can select only within specified hierarchy levels, improving accuracy in data selection and reducing manual review and correction efforts. (Learn more.)


Integration Support for Supplier Qualification Status (SLP-2387)

This feature adds support for synchronizing supplier qualification status to integrated ERP systems using custom generic fields. This change allows you to access up-to-date qualification information directly in the ERP system, facilitating automated decision-making processes such as blocking suppliers with expired qualifications. (Learn more.)


Ability to Restrict the Number of Commodity, Region, and Department Answers in Process Intake Forms (SLP-2392)

This feature enables you to configure the maximum number of answers process initiators can add to Commodity, Region, and Department questions in process intake forms. (Learn more.)


Ability to Perform Real-time Validation and Version Comparison for Supplier Questionnaire (SLP-2377)

This feature enables you to validate the data in real-time for supplier responses to external questionnaires. It allows buyers to compare validated current responses with previously approved versions. This enhances data accuracy and compliance with buyer standards. It also accelerates supplier onboarding. (Learn more.)


Additional Project Header Fields for Conditional Approvals (SLP-2386)

This feature increases the number of project header fields available for creating conditional approval workflows beyond the current six fields. This change allows you to create more conditional approval flows per questionnaire. (Learn more.)


Ability to Restrict Hierarchy Level Selection for Department and Region in Modular Questionnaire Configuration (SLP-2408)

With this feature, template creators can configure hierarchy level selection restrictions in the modular questionnaire template for Department and Region question types in the same way they can for Commodity questions . Respondents can select only within specified hierarchy levels, improving accuracy in data selection and reducing manual review and correction efforts. (Learn more.)


Additional AI Copilot Joule Capabilities for Finding Suppliers, Supplier Contacts, and Supplier Management Projects (SLP-2411)

This feature adds capabilities for using AI copilot Joule to find more information about suppliers and supplier management projects, including approval status and pending approvers for projects created by the current user, qualified and preferred suppliers, and suppliers with expiring or expired certificates. It also enhances the scenario for finding supplier contact information. (Learn more.)

 

Supplier Performance Evaluations in SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance (NGSM-2269)

This feature allows buyers to create and manage programs for conducting periodic supplier performance evaluations, which evaluate suppliers for performance based on key indicators determined by your organization. (Learn more.)

 

Supplier Risk

Ability to Enhance Risk Control Effectiveness by Automating Residual Risk Calculation (NGSM-1273)

This feature enables you to automate the effectiveness review of risk controls by using modular questionnaire scoring based on predefined criteria, eliminating the need for manual assessment. (Learn more.)


Ability to Create an Engagement Request from a Supplier Request Data (SRISK-1878)

This feature enables you to create engagement requests directly from approved supplier requests, removing repetitive manual steps and ensuring data consistency between supplier requests and engagement requests. You will receive a pop up message once the engagement request is created. (Learn more.)


Enhancing Supplier Risk Exposure API By Adding New Data Fields in Response (SRISK-1887)

This feature introduces a new version of the Supplier Risk Exposure API. In addition with the exposure details in the response, this new version has additional two fields data in the API response. (Learn more.)

 

Stay connected with your community for more insights and updates:

  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement  
  • What’s New

entry.title: Re: Project Budget Report Is not Working Properly
entry.content:
You’re seeing two symptoms:

  • No commitments in project reports after PR/PO posting (Account Assignment P and Q).
  • Double amounts in the Project Financial Booklet compared to the Cost Report.

This points to commitment update/derivation issues between Purchasing and Project Budget Availability Control (AVC), plus a reduction logic mismatch (PR vs. PO).

entry.title: SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026): Useful Guide of Next‑Gen GRC
entry.content:
Table of Contents

  • 1. Introduction:
  • 2. Modules of SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026)
  • 3. SAP Roadmap and plan for SAP GRC solutions
  • 4. Release Dates for SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026)
  • 4.1. Early Adopter Customers
  • 4.2. Regular Customers
  • 5. How to Migrate to SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026) from SAP GRC v1200?
  • 6. Few New features of SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026)
  • 6.1. SAP Access Control
  • 6.2. SAP Process Control
  • 6.3. SAP Risk Management
  • 6.4. SAP Audit Management
  • 6.5. SAP Business Integrity Screening
  • 6.6. SAP Tax Compliance
  • 6.7. SAP UIDP Masking
  • 6.8. SAP UIDP Logging
  • 7. Key characteristics
  • 8. Licensing model
  • 9. Benefits
  • 10.Conclusion

 

1.     Introduction:

SAP is entering a major transformation phase in Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC). With the introduction of SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026), SAP is consolidating and modernizing its entire GRC portfolio to support S/4HANA, cloud adoption, real‑time analytics, and continuous compliance.

SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 has quickly become one of the most discussed topics among organizations, leaders, IT directors, managers, SMEs, consultants, and vendors working in SAP Security and GRC. This 2026 release is designed for both on‑premise and private cloud deployments. It is ideal for organizations that want to remain on‑premise or private cloud while maintaining long‑term GRC capabilities, especially those using or planning to use modules such as SAP Process Control or SAP Risk Management.

SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 is SAP’s next‑generation unified GRC platform, built natively on SAP HANA.

 

2.     Modules of SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026)

Within SAP’s GRC portfolio, there are multiple solutions that cover both on‑premise and cloud‑based offerings.

 To learn more about the on‑premise SAP GRC solutions, you may refer to the blog  Kickstart your SAP GRC Learning Journey: Introduction to SAP GRC, Submodules and useful links

 To learn more about the cloud SAP GRC solutions, you may refer to the blog  Kickstart your Cloud SAP GRC Learning Journey: Introduction to Cloud SAP GRC, its Submodules details

 SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 is delivered as a single unified software component that includes all 8 of the following modules:

  • SAP Access Control
  • SAP Process Control
  • SAP Risk Management
  • SAP Audit Management
  • SAP Tax Compliance
  • SAP Business Integrity Screening
  • SAP UI Data Protection Masking
  • SAP UI Data Protection Logging

Image source: SAP

3.     SAP Roadmap and plan for SAP GRC solutions

See below SAP Road map of existing SAP GRC v1200 and new SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 along with modules it it.

Image source: SAP

You may refer to the Details for Product Version SAP GRC FOR SAP HANA 1.0

 

4.     Release Dates for SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026)

4.1.           Early Adopter Customers

If you have already registered as a Early Adopters, SAP planned to release in March 2026.

4.2.           Regular Customers

For General/regular availability it will be early Q3-2026

5.     How to Migrate to SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026) from SAP GRC v1200?

Organizations can choose the “Hub Model” or “Embedded Model” for their SAP GRC for HANA (SAP GRC 2026) upgrade/migration.  In case if an existing Hub Model setup customer wants to move to Embedded model, it is like a new implementation of SAP GRC for HANA 2026 but can reuse existing GRC design.

To migrate from SAP GRCv1200 to SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026), this requires below 2 prerequisites

  1. SAP NetWeaver should be minimum SAP S/4HANA Foundation (it is just an upgraded version for SAP NetWeaver). This is not SAP S/4HANA full version. Organizations who are using SAP Fiori 2.0 would have already migrated their SAP NetWeaver to SAP S/4HANA Foundation. Incase if you are having lower version of GRC Support pack or still on Fiori 1.0 or using SAP NetWeaver as a base component for SAP GRC, then this is a mandatory step.  In case for an Embedded GRC model, SAP GRC for HANA 2026 can be installed on S4Core.
  2. Databased as HANA DB: SAP GRC for HANA1.0 only supports SAP HANA DB, Organizations are forced to migrate their Non-HANA Database to HANA DB.

Once the above prerequisites are complete, SAP GRC v12.0 can be upgraded to SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 release as part of their standard maintenance program, meaning no new SKU or additional purchase is required.

 

6.     Few New features of SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026)

6.1.           SAP Access Control

  • Augmented Access request process
  • AI supported User Access Review process
  • AI driven Emergency Access Management log review process for monitoring, identifying and responding to potential security threats
  • Fiori based Access Request and approver process
  • Compliance reporting with extended analytics
  • Out of the box Fiori based reports – OVP
  • Additional Data source – Integrating Identity Services IdDs
  • SuccessFactors – Expand rulesets to include target populations
  • New EAM logs for Read Access Logs (RAL)
  • New Fiori App for Approval Work inbox

6.2.           SAP Process Control

  • SAP Joule integration to create Data Source and Business rules, also to understand the table and required logic.
  • Issue Analytics: Smartness for issue analysis and resolution
  • MSMP is extended to PC workflows
  • No new enhancements for Policy Management
  • Improved User Experience: Utilizing Fiori Apps for enhanced usability and accessibility (My Compliance Tasks, MCP, Assessments, Intelligent Self Diagnostic)
  • Single Entry Control Screen: Streamlining operation (Manage Controls)
  • Intelligent Self-Diagnostic Cockpit: Error analysis and resolution capabilities (CCM)
  • Enhanced Integration: Leveraging the SAP Integration Suite and Framework for seamless connectivity
  • Flexible Workflow Management: Adapting to business needs with customizable workflows
  • Regulatory Alignment: Integrating with Regulatory Insights for compliance and oversight

6.3.           SAP Risk Management

  • Harmonized Email Notification – Planner/Scheduler enhancement
  • Business Continuity Management
  • MSMP is extended to RM workflows
  • SAP Joule integration to create KRIs, also to understand the tables/CDS views etc.

6.4.           SAP Audit Management

  • Overview page for Audit Coverage
  • Import Master Data from PC/RM in same system per the push of a button
  • Inspection Management module
  • Consolidate email notifications for multiple actions
  • AI Supported Audit Report Generation
  • AI Supported work program preparation

6.5.           SAP Business Integrity Screening

  • Fiori apps for Detection Runs
  • Improving performance for Managing Alerts App

6.6.           SAP Tax Compliance

  • Bulk Edit User group attributes

6.7.           SAP UIDP Masking

  • Extending UI Masking to ODATA V4 applications and BW/4AHNA scenarios
  • Configurations need to be done in Central S/4 or S/4Foundation system
  • No need to install it in each connected system.

6.8.           SAP UIDP Logging

  • Streamlined UI lugging optimized for SAP HANA
  • Configurations need to be done in Central S/4 or S/4Foundation system
  • No need to install it in each connected system.

7.     Key characteristics

  • Built on SAP HANA
  • HANA DB is mandatory
  • Fiori‑based user experience
  • Real‑time analytics
  • Cloud‑ready architecture
  • Integration with SAP Joule, BTP, SAP IAG, SAP Cloud Identity Services

8.     Licensing model

Licence is still separate for each GRC module; hence customers need to buy a separate licence based on required module.

9.     Benefits

  • Unified GRC platform
  • AI Integration
  • Easier deployment
  • Reduced complexity
  • Reduce TOC with increased ROI
  • Modern Fiori UX
  • Improved Reporting
  • Future‑proof roadmap

10.Conclusion

SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026) is more than an upgrade — it is a complete modernization of SAP’s GRC landscape. It brings real‑time capabilities, unified architecture, cloud readiness, and a simplified user experience.

For organizations, leaders, IT directors, managers, SMEs, consultants, and vendors, now is the time to:
- Understand the new platform
- Assess your current GRC landscape
- Plan your migration strategy
- Align with SAP’s long‑term roadmap

The future of GRC is real‑time, automated, cloud‑ready, and unified — and SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 is the platform that delivers it.

#SAP GRC #SAP GRC 2026  #SAP GRC for HANA 1.0

entry.title: Integrate GitHub with SAP Cloud Integration using Open Connectors: Fetch & Decode File Content
entry.content:
Integrating our systems with third-party platforms like GitHub has become a common requirement in today’s business landscape, especially when working with public repositories that store documentation and configuration files.

In this blog post, I’ll walk you through how to connect SAP Open Connectors for GitHub with SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) to fetch a file from a GitHub repository and decode its contents. We’ll use SAP Open Connectors to securely access GitHub resources and apply a Groovy script in CPI to decode the Base64-encoded file content, helping you build a simple and reliable end-to-end integration.

By the end of this blog, you’ll have a clear understanding of how to:

1. Set up a GitHub instance in SAP Open Connectors

2.Connect SAP Open Connectors with SAP Cloud Integration (CPI)

Step 1: Fetching and decoding file content using Groovy scripting

To begin, you first need to create a GitHub instance in SAP Open Connectors. Start by logging in to the SAP BTP Cockpit and navigating to the SAP Open Connectors dashboard. This is where you’ll configure and manage your GitHub connection before using it in SAP Cloud Integration.

 

To get started, select the GitHub connector from the list of available connectors in SAP Open Connectors.

 

Next, enter your GitHub details. Provide your GitHub account name and the repository name. Make sure the repository you choose is public, as this is required for access without additional authentication

Once the details are filled in, click Create Instance. This will open the configuration screen where you can complete the setup for your GitHub instance.

 

Step 2: Testing GitHub APIs using Interactive API Docs

Before connecting everything to SAP Cloud Integration, it’s a good practice to test the GitHub connector using the Interactive API Docs provided by SAP Open Connectors. This helps confirm that your GitHub instance is correctly configured and able to retrieve data from your repository.

To do this, open the GitHub instance you just created from the SAP Open Connectors dashboard and navigate to the Interactive API Docs section.

Here, you’ll need to provide the required parameter, such as the file path within the repository (for example, /notes.md). After submitting the request, you’ll receive a JSON response.

After submitting the request, you’ll receive a JSON response. One of the key fields in this response is the content field, which contains the file data encoded in Base64 format.

This confirms that your GitHub instance is set up correctly and is able to access files from the specified public repository. In the next steps, this Base64-encoded content will be decoded in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) using a Groovy script.

 

Step 3: Storing Open Connectors Credentials in Security Material

Before using SAP Open Connectors in your iFlow, you need to store the required credentials in SAP Integration Suite.

 

Step 4: Connecting SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) to GitHub using Open Connectors

Once your GitHub instance is set up and running, the next step is to connect it with SAP Cloud Integration so you can retrieve file content from the repository.

To do this, start by creating a new iFlow in your CPI workspace. Add a Sender step, such as a Timer or HTTPS adapter, based on how you want to trigger the flow. Then, add a Receiver step.

For the Receiver, choose the Open Connectors adapter from the list of available adapters. This adapter will be used to connect CPI with GitHub through SAP Open Connectors.

 

Deploy the iFlow and trigger it to run. This will call the GitHub API and fetch the file content, which is returned in a Base64-encoded format.

Once the file content is successfully retrieved from GitHub, you’ll see a response similar to the one shown below.

 

Step 5: Fetching and decoding the file content

At this stage, the file content fetched from GitHub is still in Base64 format, which isn’t readable. To convert it into plain text, you can use a Groovy Script step in your iFlow.

Add a Script step and use the following Groovy code to decode the content:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import java.util.Base64

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(String)
    def json = new groovy.json.JsonSlurper().parseText(body)
    def encodedContent = json.content
    def decodedBytes = Base64.decoder.decode(encodedContent)
    def plainText = new String(decodedBytes, "UTF-8")
    message.setBody(plainText)
    return message
}

 

This script reads the Base64-encoded content from the API response, decodes it, and replaces the message body with the decoded, human-readable text.

After the Groovy script runs successfully, the file content appears as plain text, making it easy to read and use in further processing steps.

Conclusion :

In this blog, we explored how to connect to a public GitHub repository, retrieve file content, and decode it using Groovy scripting in CPI. In the next blog, we’ll take this a step further and look at how to work with private repositories using authentication tokens.

If you have any questions or would like a downloadable iFlow sample, feel free to drop a comment.

entry.title: Re: Billing Engine Configuration - Resource Allocation Ba...
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for Professional Services, the billing engine is designed to use actuals (recorded time and expenses) as the basis for billing. Using planned hours directly for billing is not supported out of the box; instead, planned hours can drive fixed‑price or forecast billing scenarios, but not time‑and‑material billing.
Check this SAP Help Managing Billing for Services  which confirms Billing plans can be tied to milestones or fixed amounts, but they do not consume planned hours directly.

entry.title: Re: UB stock transport order miss conditioln tab
entry.content:
Why you don’t see PI01 in Public Cloud STOs is because of the scope limitation. The “Pricing in Stock Transport Orders” scope item (available in S/4HANA PCE / On-Premise) is not part of the Public Cloud standard scope. In Public Cloud, STOs are simplified: they handle material movement and delivery scheduling, but not intercompany pricing conditions.

If you need PI01 (intercompany price) in STOs, you must activate the scope item 2EJ – Intercompany Stock Transfer with Delivery or 2EL – Intercompany Stock Transfer with Billing. These scope items enable pricing and billing integration for STOs. Verify if 2EJ (Intercompany STO with Delivery) or 2EL (Intercompany STO with Billing) are activated. Without these, STOs will not have condition tabs.

If you only need valuation for internal transfers (not intercompany billing), use valuation price determination in material master / accounting view. If you need commercial pricing (PI01), you must use intercompany STO scope items.
